epidemiology: Autoimmune destruction of pancreatic beta cells. Commonly presents in children and young adults. Incidence: ~15 per 100,000/year in children.

emergency_markers: DKA symptoms: nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, confusion

treatment_protocol: Start insulin → Educate on hypoglycemia → Monitor HbA1c regularly

epidemiology: Most common type of diabetes; associated with obesity, insulin resistance, and sedentary lifestyle. Prevalence rising globally.
treatment_protocol: Start metformin → Add agents as needed → Monitor complications

epidemiology: Most common cause of hyperthyroidism. Autoimmune; more frequent in women aged 20–40.

emergency_markers: Fever, confusion, tachycardia in thyroid storm

treatment_protocol: Confirm hyperthyroidism → Start anti-thyroid drugs → Consider RAI or surgery

epidemiology: Most common cause of hypothyroidism in iodine-sufficient regions. Autoimmune. More common in women.
treatment_protocol: Diagnose with TSH + antibodies → Start thyroxine → Monitor TSH

epidemiology: Due to excess cortisol; can be ACTH-dependent (pituitary/adrenal tumor) or exogenous. Rare, but important to diagnose.
treatment_protocol: Confirm hypercortisolism → Localize source → Treat cause

epidemiology: Primary adrenal insufficiency; autoimmune etiology most common in developed countries; affects 1 in 100,000 people.
treatment_protocol: Confirm diagnosis → Replace glucocorticoids/mineralocorticoids → Educate on stress dosing

epidemiology: Catecholamine-producing tumor of adrenal medulla; rare but important cause of secondary hypertension.
treatment_protocol: Alpha-blockade → Beta-blockade → Surgery → Monitor recurrence

epidemiology: Excess growth hormone (GH), usually due to pituitary adenoma; prevalence ~60 per million.

emergency_markers: Pituitary apoplexy symptoms (headache + vision loss + vomiting)

treatment_protocol: Confirm GH excess → MRI → Surgery → Monitor IGF-1 levels

epidemiology: Primary form most common in postmenopausal women; secondary common in CKD; tertiary occurs after prolonged secondary.
treatment_protocol: Confirm elevated calcium + PTH → Imaging → Surgery if symptomatic or criteria met

epidemiology: Can be central (ADH deficiency) or nephrogenic (renal resistance); rare. Central form more common.
treatment_protocol: Differentiate type via water deprivation → Start appropriate therapy

epidemiology: Most commonly caused by surgical removal of parathyroid glands; rare inherited forms also exist.
treatment_protocol: Correct calcium → Monitor electrolytes → Consider PTH replacement

epidemiology: Common benign tumors of the pituitary gland; may be functional or non-functional; incidence ~1 in 1000.
treatment_protocol: Classify tumor → Surgery if compressive → Medical treatment for secreting tumors

epidemiology: Life-threatening complication of untreated or poorly controlled hyperthyroidism. Rare but critical.

emergency_markers: Fever, AMS, tachycardia in known hyperthyroidism

treatment_protocol: Supportive care → Inhibit hormone synthesis → Prevent peripheral conversion

epidemiology: Rare, life-threatening manifestation of severe hypothyroidism. Seen in elderly or untreated patients.
treatment_protocol: Suspect based on clinical picture → Start IV thyroxine + steroids immediately

epidemiology: Most often due to adrenal adenoma (Conn's syndrome) or bilateral adrenal hyperplasia; cause of secondary hypertension.

emergency_markers: Severe hypokalemia with arrhythmia or paralysis

treatment_protocol: Screen with ARR → Confirm → Treat surgically or medically

epidemiology: Autosomal dominant disorder involving tumors in parathyroid, pancreas, and pituitary. Incidence: ~1 in 30,000.
treatment_protocol: Genetic confirmation → Screening of associated tumors → Treat individually

epidemiology: Autosomal dominant disorder with medullary thyroid cancer, pheochromocytoma, and hyperparathyroidism. RET mutation positive.
treatment_protocol: Screen mutation → Remove thyroid early → Monitor and treat other components

epidemiology: Autosomal recessive disorder of adrenal steroid synthesis. 21-hydroxylase deficiency accounts for ~95% of cases.
treatment_protocol: Confirm diagnosis → Replace hormones → Monitor growth and puberty

epidemiology: Genetic condition in males (47,XXY karyotype); affects 1 in 500–1,000 males. Common cause of male hypogonadism.
treatment_protocol: Confirm with karyotype → Start testosterone in adolescence → Monitor bone and fertility

epidemiology: Monosomy X (45,X) in females. Affects ~1 in 2,500 live female births. Causes primary ovarian failure.

emergency_markers: Coarctation of aorta or congenital heart defects in infancy

treatment_protocol: Diagnose early → Start GH → Add estrogen in adolescence

epidemiology: X-linked recessive condition affecting 1 in 20,000 to 64,000 male births; complete or partial androgen resistance.
treatment_protocol: Diagnose with karyotype + phenotype → Monitor → Gonadectomy post-puberty

epidemiology: Postpartum pituitary infarction due to massive hemorrhage; more common in low-resource settings.

emergency_markers: Severe hypotension in postpartum woman with lactation failure

treatment_protocol: Suspect in postpartum hemorrhage → Confirm with MRI and labs → Start hormones

epidemiology: Rare pancreatic beta-cell tumor; most common functional pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor; incidence ~1-4/million/year.
treatment_protocol: Confirm endogenous hyperinsulinism → Localize tumor → Surgical excision

epidemiology: Most common type of pituitary tumor; does not secrete hormones; presents due to mass effect.
treatment_protocol: Imaging → Surgical resection if symptomatic or growing → Monitor hormone levels

epidemiology: Partial or complete deficiency of anterior pituitary hormones; causes include tumors, Sheehan’s, trauma, infection.

definitive: Hormone replacement (thyroid, cortisol, sex steroids, GH)

treatment_protocol: Confirm hormone deficiencies → Replace hormones accordingly → Monitor response

epidemiology: Rare catecholamine-secreting tumor, mostly from adrenal medulla. Incidence: 2–8 cases/million/year.
treatment_protocol: Control BP with alpha-blockers → Surgery → Follow up for recurrence

epidemiology: Most common cause of hypercalcemia in outpatients. Incidence increases with age; more common in women.

emergency_markers: Severe hypercalcemia with altered mental status

treatment_protocol: Evaluate calcium and PTH → Imaging → Surgery for definitive cure

epidemiology: Primary adrenal failure. Rare, prevalence: ~100 per million. Often autoimmune in origin.
treatment_protocol: Confirm diagnosis → Start steroids → Educate patient on stress dosing

epidemiology: Rare disorder of ADH deficiency. Can be idiopathic or due to trauma, tumors, or surgery.
treatment_protocol: Water deprivation → Desmopressin response test → Treat with DDAVP

epidemiology: Caused by renal resistance to ADH. May be congenital or acquired (lithium, hypercalcemia).

emergency_markers: Severe dehydration and hypernatremia in infants/children

treatment_protocol: Differentiate from central DI → Start thiazides → Monitor electrolytes

epidemiology: Excess aldosterone production due to adrenal adenoma or hyperplasia. Affects ~5–10% of hypertensive patients.
treatment_protocol: Confirm with ARR → Imaging → Surgery (unilateral) or medical therapy (bilateral)

epidemiology: Deficiency of aldosterone or resistance to its action; common in elderly diabetics or those on RAAS blockers.
treatment_protocol: Diagnose → Manage potassium → Replace mineralocorticoid if needed

epidemiology: Benign inherited condition with lifelong mild hypercalcemia due to CaSR gene mutation.
treatment_protocol: Differentiate from PHPT → Avoid unnecessary surgery

epidemiology: Autoimmune inflammation of orbital tissues seen in ~25–50% of patients with Graves’ disease.

emergency_markers: Decreased visual acuity, afferent pupillary defect

treatment_protocol: Treat underlying thyroid disease → Manage orbitopathy severity

epidemiology: Rare chronic fibrosing thyroiditis; part of IgG4-related disease spectrum. More common in middle-aged women.
treatment_protocol: Biopsy to confirm → Start steroids → Decompress surgically if needed

epidemiology: Most common cause of hyperthyroidism. Peak incidence in women aged 20–40 years.
treatment_protocol: Confirm hyperthyroidism → Antithyroid drugs → Definitive therapy (RAI or surgery)

epidemiology: Most common cause of hypothyroidism in iodine-sufficient areas. Affects women more frequently (10:1).
treatment_protocol: Confirm diagnosis → Start thyroid hormone replacement → Monitor TSH

epidemiology: Self-limiting thyroid inflammation often post-viral. More common in middle-aged women.
treatment_protocol: Symptom control → Steroids if needed → Monitor recovery

epidemiology: Life-threatening complication of untreated or poorly controlled hyperthyroidism. High mortality if untreated.

emergency_markers: Severe hyperthyroid symptoms with systemic decompensation

treatment_protocol: Urgent ICU care → Antithyroid meds → Supportive therapy

epidemiology: Rare, life-threatening decompensated hypothyroidism. Occurs mostly in elderly women with longstanding disease.
treatment_protocol: ICU → IV thyroid + steroids → Correct electrolytes

epidemiology: Autosomal recessive disorder due to enzyme deficiencies (most commonly 21-hydroxylase). Incidence: 1 in 15,000 births.
treatment_protocol: Diagnose biochemically → Replace steroids → Monitor growth and electrolytes

epidemiology: Due to excess cortisol. Endogenous (ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma or adrenal tumor) or exogenous (steroids).
treatment_protocol: Confirm diagnosis → Identify cause → Surgery or steroid taper

epidemiology: Excess prolactin often due to pituitary adenoma. Also caused by medications or hypothyroidism.

emergency_markers: Visual field loss from pituitary mass

treatment_protocol: Rule out secondary causes → Treat tumor medically or surgically

epidemiology: Deficiency of one or more pituitary hormones. Caused by pituitary tumors, trauma, surgery, or infarction.

definitive: Hormone replacement (thyroxine, steroids, sex hormones, GH)

treatment_protocol: Diagnose hormone deficiencies → Replace in correct order → Monitor regularly

epidemiology: Postpartum pituitary necrosis due to severe blood loss. Rare but serious cause of hypopituitarism.

definitive: Hormone replacement for all deficient hormones

treatment_protocol: Suspect in postpartum shock → Confirm low hormones → Replace accordingly

epidemiology: Autosomal dominant disorder with tumors in parathyroid, pancreas, and pituitary. Rare, incidence ~1 in 30,000.
treatment_protocol: Screen family → Surveillance → Treat each tumor appropriately

epidemiology: Autosomal dominant syndrome with medullary thyroid cancer, pheochromocytoma, and hyperparathyroidism.
treatment_protocol: RET testing → Thyroidectomy → Treat pheochromocytoma and hyperparathyroidism

epidemiology: Rare pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor secreting insulin. Incidence: ~4 per million/year. Most are benign.
treatment_protocol: Confirm endogenous insulin → Localize tumor → Surgery

epidemiology: Rare pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor producing glucagon. Often malignant. Usually in older adults.
treatment_protocol: Diagnose biochemically → Localize tumor → Surgery ± medical therapy

epidemiology: Very rare neuroendocrine tumor secreting somatostatin. Usually malignant and located in pancreas or duodenum.
treatment_protocol: Biochemical confirmation → Imaging → Resection

epidemiology: Occurs in patients with carcinoid tumors (neuroendocrine), usually after liver metastases. Incidence ~1–2 per 100,000/year.
risk_factors: Midgut carcinoid tumors with liver metastasis
treatment_protocol: Biochemical confirmation → Imaging → Medical therapy ± surgery

epidemiology: Rare catecholamine-secreting tumor from adrenal medulla. Accounts for <0.2% of hypertension cases.

emergency_markers: Sudden severe hypertension with crisis features

treatment_protocol: Biochemical diagnosis → Alpha-blockade → Surgery

epidemiology: Characterized by ADH deficiency (central) or renal resistance (nephrogenic). Rare condition.
treatment_protocol: Differentiate central vs nephrogenic → Treat accordingly

epidemiology: Common cause of hyponatremia in hospitalized patients. Associated with CNS disorders, malignancy, and drugs.
treatment_protocol: Identify cause → Fluid restriction → Correct sodium slowly

epidemiology: Gastrin-secreting tumor (gastrinoma), usually in pancreas or duodenum. Associated with MEN 1.
treatment_protocol: Confirm gastrinoma → Control acid → Localize and resect

epidemiology: A rare and severe form of congenital adrenal hyperplasia caused by mutations in the StAR gene, leading to impaired steroidogenesis.

emergency_markers: Severe dehydration and hypotension in neonates

treatment_protocol: Identify adrenal crisis → Hormonal assays → Confirm genetically → Hormone replacement

epidemiology: Benign autosomal dominant disorder caused by mutations in the calcium-sensing receptor (CaSR). Often confused with primary hyperparathyroidism.
treatment_protocol: Differentiate from hyperparathyroidism → Avoid unnecessary surgery

epidemiology: Rare genetic disorder involving GNAS gene mutations leading to endocrine hyperfunction, fibrous dysplasia, and café-au-lait spots.
treatment_protocol: Multidisciplinary approach → Monitor growth/hormones → Manage complications

epidemiology: Common in older adults, especially of European descent. Characterized by abnormal bone remodeling.
treatment_protocol: Diagnose with labs/imaging → Treat with bisphosphonates → Monitor bone turnover

epidemiology: Vitamin D deficiency causing defective bone mineralization in children. Common in developing countries.

important: Serum calcium, phosphate, ALP, vitamin D

treatment_protocol: Correct deficiency → Monitor biochemistry → Prevent deformities

epidemiology: Caused by adrenal adenoma or bilateral adrenal hyperplasia. Accounts for ~5–10% of hypertension cases.
treatment_protocol: Confirm diagnosis → Localize lesion → Treat appropriately

epidemiology: Deficiency of aldosterone secretion or action. Can be due to primary adrenal disease or hyporeninemic hypoaldosteronism.
treatment_protocol: Evaluate potassium → Confirm diagnosis → Replace mineralocorticoid

epidemiology: Rare, aggressive tumor with bimodal age distribution. May secrete cortisol, androgens, estrogens, or aldosterone.
treatment_protocol: Confirm tumor → Hormone workup → Surgery ± chemo

epidemiology: Genetic disorder causing hypogonadotropic hypogonadism and anosmia. More common in males.
treatment_protocol: Confirm hormone deficiency → Imaging → Replace hormones

epidemiology: X-linked recessive disorder in genetic males (46,XY) with resistance to androgens. Complete form results in female phenotype.
treatment_protocol: Confirm diagnosis → Manage hormones → Remove gonads post-puberty

epidemiology: Autosomal dominant disorder involving tumors of parathyroid, pancreas, and pituitary. Incidence: ~1 in 30,000.
treatment_protocol: Screen at-risk individuals → Monitor biochemistry → Treat surgically or medically

epidemiology: Genetic syndrome with medullary thyroid carcinoma, pheochromocytoma, and parathyroid tumors. Caused by RET mutation.
treatment_protocol: Genetic screening → Monitor markers → Prophylactic treatment

epidemiology: Postpartum pituitary necrosis due to severe hypotension/hemorrhage. More common in resource-limited settings.
treatment_protocol: Stabilize acute crisis → Hormonal replacement → Long-term follow-up

epidemiology: Radiologic finding where sella turcica is partially or completely filled with CSF. May be incidental or cause hypopituitarism.
treatment_protocol: MRI diagnosis → Monitor or replace hormones

epidemiology: Rare disorder usually due to surgical removal of parathyroid glands or autoimmune destruction.
treatment_protocol: Identify cause → Correct calcium → Long-term supplementation

epidemiology: A rare genetic disorder characterized by resistance to PTH, leading to hypocalcemia and hyperphosphatemia despite high PTH levels.

definitive: Calcium and active vitamin D supplementation

treatment_protocol: Identify biochemical profile → Confirm diagnosis → Replace calcium/vitamin D

epidemiology: Rare pancreatic beta-cell tumor causing endogenous hyperinsulinemia and hypoglycemia. Most common functional pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor.
treatment_protocol: Confirm biochemical diagnosis → Localize tumor → Surgical excision

epidemiology: Life-threatening complication of untreated/undertreated hyperthyroidism. Precipitated by stress, surgery, or infection.
treatment_protocol: Stabilize patient → Antithyroid therapy → Treat trigger

epidemiology: Acute metabolic complication of type 2 diabetes. Common in elderly with infections or poor fluid intake.
treatment_protocol: Stabilize fluid/electrolytes → Insulin infusion → Identify triggers

epidemiology: Rare alpha-cell tumor of pancreas. Presents with characteristic rash and diabetes. Often malignant.
treatment_protocol: Confirm with labs/imaging → Manage symptoms → Tumor resection
